sp.p:
for the Church I cannot conceive
anything better for the art of a
culture of a country than the presence
in it of a body of men whose duty it
is to believe in the supernatural, to
perform daily miracles, and to keep
alive that mythopoeic faculty which is
so essential for the imagination. But
in the English Church a man succeeds
not in proper through his capacity for
belief but through his capacity for
disbelief. Ours is the only Church where
the sceptic stands at the altar, and
where St. Thomas is regarded as the
ideal apostle. Many a worthy clergyman
who passes his life in admirable works
of kindly charity lives and dies
unnoticed and unknown; but it is sufficient
for some shallow uneducated passman
out of either University to get up in
his pulpit and express his doubts
about Noah's ark, or Balaam's ass, or
Jonah and the whale, for the whole half of
London to flock to hear him, and to
sit open-mouthed in rapt admiration
at his superb intellect. The growth of
common sense in the English Church is
a thing very much to be regretted. It is
really a degrading concession to a low form
of realism. However, I must read the end
of my article.Typesetter's Signature: Deely
